                                                                                                                          the lightest gnat resting on the glands of the leaves of one
                                                                                                                          of these species excites the minute hairs with which they are
                                                                                                                          covered and causes the leaf to close, and Dr. Sanderson has
                                                                                                                          shown that the same kind of electrical current is set up in
                                                                                                                          the leaf by this movement, as occurs in our own muscles
                                                                                                                          when they contract.   The glands of the leaf next begin to
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          pour out a sticky fluid, which dissolves the substances of
                                                                                                                          the insect in just the same proportions             and in the same
                                                                                                                          manner as the gastric juice of our stomach dissolves the
                                                                                                                          substances in our food, and lastly, when the leaf unfolds, and
                                                                                                                          the tentacles or little hairs rise up again, letting the refuse    of
                                                                                                                          the dead insect drop, the glands cease to give out the fluid
                                                                                                                          until another insect is caught and the process begins again.
                                                                                                                          The whole history of these carnivorous plants, though they are
                                                                                                                          exceptional in the vegetable kingdom, is one of the most in
                                                                                                                          teresting that can be imagined, and forms another unexpected
                                                                                                                          link between the nature of plants and animals.
                                                                                                                              Lastly, we cannot leave the subject of botany without
                                                                                                                          mentioning           important and interesting discoveries
                                                                                                                                        the most
                                                                                                                          made in our day about the formation of seeds and spores,
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          and the whole question of fertilisation.             We have seen
                                                                                                                          how Sprengel first pointed out the use              of the visits of
                                                                                                                          insects   to flowers, but even   he   could    have    had no con
                                                                                                                          ception    of the   marvellous               of plants
                                                                                                                                                           inter-independence
                                                                                                                          and insects which has now been shown to exist by Her
                                                                                                                          mann Miiller, Mr. Darwin, Kerner, and others, proving
                                                                                                                          that even the    minutest hairs and prickles on a plant have

                                                                                                                          ch. x1.II.               ADVANCES          IN   ZOOLOGY.                    471
                                                                                                                          a meaning               one insect, or keeping off another,
                                                                                                                                            in inviting
                                                                                                                          while almost all the beautiful colours and curious forms of
                                                                                                                          flowers serve the same purpose.1                 Nor has the study of the
                                                                                                                          seed-cases       of the ferns and mosses proved less interesting,
                                                                                                                          for here the microscope reveals a wholly unsuspected his
                                                                                                                          tory of fertilisation carried on by organs so minute that they
                                                                                                                          were almost disregarded by the older botanists.         These
                                                                                                                          organs have now been                made    the objects    of special study
                                                                                                                          by such men as Bornet, Thuret, Schimper, de Bary, and
                                                                                                                          others, and they form in themselves almost a separate branch
                                                                                                                          of science.        All   these studies have grown up          of late years,
                                                                                                                          together with a wonderful increase   in our knowledge con
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          cerning the effects of climate, soil, and the distribution of
                                                                                                                          land upon the spread            of different       species   of plants and
                                                                                                                          the nature   of the homes in which we find them, so that the
                                                                                                                          science of botany now covers a wide range of subjects such
                                                                                                                          as were little dreamed of by such men as earnest old Gesner,
                                                                                                                          who sowed the first seed of this interesting study when in
                                                                                                                          155    1    he laid out the first botanical garden (see p. 67).
                                                                                                                             Zoology. — In zoology the advance in our century has
                                                                                                                          been, if anything, greater than in botany. The work done
                                                                                                                          by Cuvier   and his fellow-labourers opened the way for a
                                                                                                                          new classification of animals, founded on a real know
                                                                                                                          ledge of their structure        ;    while the discoveries which have
                                                                                                                          been        made of extinct animals has helped us to fill many a
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          gap and explain many puzzling relationships.
                                                                                                                            Zoology possesses an entirely new interest, as already
                                                                                                                          mentioned          (p.
                                                                                                                                       442), now that naturalists are inclined to
                                                                                                                          believe that all animals are descended from                  a   few simple
                                                                                                                          forms, and are therefore more or less distantly related to
                                                                                                                             1
                                                                                                                                     See Chapter on Bees and    Flowers in the Author's   '
                                                                                                                                                                                              Fairyland of
                                                                                                                          Science.'

                                                                                                                          472                NINETEENTH CENTURY.                      pt.   1n.
                                                                                                                                    The classifications of animals, as given by Owen
                                                                                                                          each other.
                                                                                                                          and Huxley in England, and Von Baer, Gegenbaur, and
                                                                                                                          Haeckel in Germany, and in fact    by all zoologists of our
                                                                                                                          time, is formed upon this conception, and so classification
                                                                                                                          becomes  no longer a mere arrangement for convenience,
                                                                                                                          but a real statement of what we know about the links
                                                                                                                          which bind the animal creation, together.       But in order to
                                                                                                                          find these links an almost incredible         amount of patient
                                                                                                                          work must be done.      It   is not enough to understand merely
                                                                                                                          the prominent characters   of an animal.   Its minutest struc
                                                                                                                          ture must be known, for those parts of least importance in
                                                                                                                          its own life are often of the greatest value to the naturalist,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          because they are the remains of some organ which was
                                                                                                                          useful to a remote ancestor.
                                                                                                                                It   is to such work       that men in our day are
                                                                                                                                                        as this
                                                                                                                          devoting years of untiring study ; and in our country no
                                                                                                                          name can rank higher in this respect than that of Pro
                                                                                                                          fessor W. Kitchen Parker, who, by his accurate investigations
                                                                                                                          in embryology, is tracing out many hidden links of structure
                                                                                                                          between widely separated orders, and laying the basis of a
                                                                                                                          true, though fragmentary, genealogical chart of the vertebrate
                                                                                                                          animals.
                                                                                                                             Again, the microscope is enabling us, in zoology, as in
                                                                                                                          botany, to recognise the earliest beginnings of organs
                                                                                                                          similar to our own, even, in the lower invertebrate animals,
                                                                                                                                         in the Medusae or jelly-fish, in which Mr.
                                                                                                                          as, for example,
                                                                                                                          Romanes has lately discovered traces of a nervous system,
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          while the rudiments of eyes, and sacs of mineral particles
                                                                                                                          forming probably a rude hearing apparatus, have also been
                                                                                                                          found in these interesting jelly-masses. When we consider,
                                                                                                                          therefore, the amount of minute investigation which is being
                                                                                                                          made into the structure      of every living thing in our days, and
                                                                                                                          the    hundreds of men who spend their lives in following

                                                                                                                          ch. xl11.               PALEONTOLOGY.                          473
                                                                                                                          out one branch or another of the animal creation, we might
                                                                                                                          almost despair of ever uniting all this knowledge into one
                                                                                                                          grand system. But by the help of the theory of relationship
                                                                                                                          this is being done, and the study of comparative anatomy
                                                                                                                          and physiology, which took its rise in John Hunter, is begin
                                                                                                                          ning now to open out to us a vast scheme of creation, in
                                                                                                                          which not only each animal, but the history of the develop
                                                                                                                          ment of the species, of the individual, and of each separate
                                                                                                                          organ,   will find its place.
                                                                                                                             Side by side with this study of living beings has grown
                                                                                                                          up the study of Palaeontology, or of fossil animals, which
                                                                                                                          Cuvier brought into such prominent notice in 18 12.   This
                                                                                                                          study shows us what life has been in the past, and year by
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          year new species   of animals are being found, which help
                                                                                                                          to complete the links between different living forms. This
                                                                                                                          is especially the case in America, where Dr. Leidy, Pro
                                                                                                                          fessor   Cope, and Professor     Marsh,    have   brought to light
                                                                                                                          an immense number                        Some of these help
                                                                                                                                                  of fossil skeletons.
                                                                                                                          us to trace the gradual development of animals — as in the
                                                                                                                          case of the horse, whose probable ancestors have now been
                                                                                                                          found among the fossils of the Rocky Mountains, beginning
                                                                                                                          with a little creature about the size of a fox, with real toes
                                                                                                                          instead of a hoof.     Others again are curious animals, half
                                                                                                                          reptiles, half birds, and some of these are so enormous, that
                                                                                                                          it is difficult to imagine how they can have walked as they
                                                                                                                          did upon their hind feet.   The largest of these monsters,
                                                                                                                          Titanosaurus montanus, found by Professor Marsh in Colorado,
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          must have measured from fifty to sixty feet in length, and
                                                                                                                          have been at least thirty feet high when it stood upright.
                                                                                                                          It lived in the Cretaceous period, or about the time when
                                                                                                                          all the chalk of our North and South Downs was being formed
                                                                                                                          in the depths of the sea.
                                                                                                                              It   is easy to see that such discoveries as these make us

                                                                                                                          474               NINETEENTH CENTURY.                           n.va.
                                                                                                                          take a much grander view of the history of animals and
                                                                                                                          their relationship than when it was believed that those
                                                                                                                          creatures   now   known   to us    were      all   that   had   existed
                                                                                                                          since the creation of the world.      And, again, with animals
                                                                                                                          as with   plants, immense advances have been made in
                                                                                                                          our    knowledge of their distribution over the earth, and
                                                                                                                          how they have      reached the     various countries        in which
                                                                                                                          we find them.      In this   study, again,     fossil forms are in
                                                                                                                          valuable, for they enable us to learn in what parts of the
                                                                                                                          world different animals have lived in past ages, as, for ex
                                                                                                                          ample, in the case of the horse, which was formerly believed
                                                                                                                          to have been always confined to Europe, until it was taken
                                                                                                                          to America   by Europeans, whereas we now learn that its
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          ancestors were American, and must have migrated to Europe
                                                                                                                          in past ages.
                                                                                                                                Concluding Remarks. — This short sketch gives but               a
                                                                                                                                               of the kind of work which is being
                                                                                                                          very imperfect glimpse
                                                                                                                          done in science in our own days.   Many important dis
                                                                                                                          coveries, such as those in electro-magnetism, physiology, and
                                                                                                                          other branches of science, have       been omitted altogether,
                                                                                                                          either because  they are too difficult, or are not yet brought
                                                                                                                          to the level of popular science.    I have also not attempted
                                                                                                                          to group those subjects which have been dealt with around
                                                                                                                          special men, as in former chapters, because to do this justly
                                                                                                                          would require much detailed explanation.    The workers
                                                                                                                          are hundreds, where in the seventeenth century they might
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          be reckoned   by units, and the whole scope of their work
                                                                                                                          cannot yet be measured.    We can therefore, in conclusion,
                                                                                                                          only try to understand the tendency of the science of our
                                                                                                                          day as compared with that of earlier centuries.
                                                                                                                             The work of the sixteenth century, as we saw (p. 81),
                                                                                                                          was to overcome that blind worship of authority which had

                                                                                                                          ch. xl11.             CONCLUDING REMARKS.                             475
                                                                                                                          sprung up during the Dark Ages, and which is the greatest
                                                                                                                          enemy to true knowledge.
                                                                                                                              In     the seventeenth      century    the   march   of    scientific
                                                                                                                          discovery     began   with    Galileo,         slowly but
                                                                                                                                                                    and advanced
                                                                                                                          triumphantly through many dangers and difficulties till it
                                                                                                                          culminated in the grand generalisations of Newton.   This
                                                                                                                          was the first great era      of modern science, especially of astro
                                                                                                                          nomy and physics, though biology also made a great stride
                                                                                                                          when Harvey demonstrated the circulation of the blood.
                                                                                                                             The eighteenth century continued the same work of
                                                                                                                          patient inquiry, completing the harmony of astronomy by
                                                                                                                          bringing the observed movements of the planets under
                                                                                                                          Newton's law of gravitation; founding chemistry upon a
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          firm basis of careful experiment ; creating the sciences of
                                                                                                                          zoology and botany, by establishing true systems of classi
                                                                                                                          fication ; discovering the hitherto almost unknown force of
                                                                                                                          electricity ; and reading in the crust of the earth the history
                                                                                                                          of the past ages of our planet.
                                                                                                                             And      so, when the nineteenth century opened, men found
                                                                                                                          themselves with       an immense         mass    of known     facts   and
                                                                                                                          careful     experiments, which had been accumulated during
                                                                                                                          the last two centuries, and which were very difficult to deal
                                                                                                                          with, because it had become almost impossible for any single
                                                                                                                          mind to grasp them all.   The scientific men of our century
                                                                                                                          have therefore become divided into two great classes. On the
                                                                                                                          one hand men have devoted themselves               to special sciences,
                                                                                                                          and even to special branches of a science, so that a man will
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          often spend his whole life in the study of one department of
                                                                                                                          chemistry or physics, or in investigating one little group of
                                                                                                                          insects;    and in this way discoveries of great value have
                                                                                                                          been made.
                                                                                                                             On the other hand, great minds among us have taken up
                                                                                                                          the separate facts collected by specialists, and have woven

                                                                                                                          476                   NINETEENTH CENTURY.                    ft.   II1.
                                                                                                                          the whole of physical science into one grand scheme. Such
                                                                                                                          men as Faraday, Sir W. Grove, Stokes, Helmholtz, Sir W.
                                                                                                                          Thomson,  and Clerk-Maxwell, together with many others,
                                                                                                                          have done their part in this work, so that now all the various
                                                                                                                          physical forces have been shown to be probably phases of one
                                                                                                                          great force appearing under many forms.   For the future no
                                                                                                                          one physical force can be studied as          if
                                                                                                                                                                   it existed by itself
                                                                                                                          alone, for each is shown to arise out of, and to pass into,
                                                                                                                          others.      Heat,     electricity,   magnetism, chemical   affinity,
                                                                                                                          motion — all are related to each other, and we cannot call
                                                                                                                          any one of them the ruler over the rest. Like the colours on
                                                                                                                          the soap-bubble, they each take their turn in appearing and
                                                                                                                          disappearing, according to the conditions under which they
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          arise. Their relations are almost infinitely complex, and
                                                                                                                          we have still much to learn about them ; but the grand fact
                                                                                                                          that they pass the one into the other has been demonstrated
                                                                                                                          in our century; and, under the names of 'the conserva
                                                                                                                          tion of energy,' and ' the correlation of the physical forces,'
                                                                                                                          is one  of the greatest results of modern science.
                                                                                                                              The same tendency may be seen in the study of those
                                                                                                                          sciences which relate to life.   Here again modern investiga
                                                                                                                          tion links together the scattered observations of ages, and
                                                                                                                          unites them all in the theory of ' evolution,' or the gradual
                                                                                                                          unfolding of nature ; a theory which has been worked out
                                                                                                                          in all its details by Herbert Spencer, one of our greatest
                                                                                                                          living    thinkers.    In
                                                                                                                                               astronomy, indeed, we already catch
                                                                                                                          a glimpse of this law in the probable formation of the
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          heavenly bodies out of gaseous star-matter ; and in the or
                                                                                                                          ganic world we find it even more firmly held by scientific
                                                                                                                          men in the belief that all the many forms of plant and
                                                                                                                          animal life have been unfolded out of a few simple forms,
                                                                                                                          just as the stem, the leaf, and the flower are evolved out of
                                                                                                                          a simple seed.

                                                                                                                          ch.   xlii.       CONCLUDING REMARKS.                        477
                                                                                                                             Whether this theory is true or not, it must be the work
                                                                                                                          of many generations to prove ; for the history of science
                                                                                                                          teaches us that nothing but truth can stand the test    of long
                                                                                                                          investigation, while no power or authority can resist in the
                                                                                                                          end that which is true.   The imperfect theory of phlogiston
                                                                                                                          did its work in gathering together many scattered facts in
                                                                                                                          chemistry, and then died a natural death when the discovery
                                                                                                                          of oxygen threw more light upon the subject ; while no
                                                                                                                          authority or persecution could suppress the true theory that
                                                                                                                          the earth moves round the sun.
                                                                                                                                It
                                                                                                                                 is of great importance that we should all learn this
                                                                                                                          lesson, to have faith in the invincible power of truth ; for it
                                                                                                                          would almost seem as if all the experience of past centuries
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-08-10 13:40 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433066369418
                                                                                                                          had hardly yet convinced us. We still, like the Aristotelians
                                                                                                                          and the judges of the Inquisition, often make hasty and
                                                                                                                          ignorant assertions, and try rather to prop up by authority
                                                                                                                          that which we believe, than to inquire earnestly whether it
                                                                                                                          is true.   Yet every page in the history of Science teaches
                                                                                                                          the contrary lesson.   So much as is true in any belief will
                                                                                                                          stand because it is true ; while that which is mistaken will
                                                                                                                          fade away before earnest and impartial examination.     Our
                                                                                                                          part is to endeavour, like the great men of whom we have
                                                                                                                          been reading, to open our eyes to the laws which surround
                                                                                                                          us, and which are only hidden from us by our ignorance.
                                                                                                                          And from whatever source we derive our knowledge, we
                                                                                                                          must remember that it is very little after all, and be ready
Public Domain in the United States, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-us-google
                                                                                                                          at all times to examine new facts, even though they may
                                                                                                                          seem to upset some of our favourite opinions ; for unless
                                                                                                                          we are so foolish as to think we know everything, it is cer
                                                                                                                          tain that we shall often find that we have been mistaken.
                                                                                                                              Those who labour in this spirit of seeking the truth
                                                                                                                          for itself will find their reward in the ever-increasing delight
                                                                                                                          they will feel in studying God's works, and in the assurance

                                                                                                                          478              NINETEENTH CENTURY.                     ft. hi.
                                                                                                                          which they will meet with at every step, that nothing can
                                                                                                                          happen except under the guidance of His laws.        True
                                                                                                                          science,like true religion, leads to an   entire and childlike
                                                                                                                          dependence upon the Invisible Ruler       of the universe.     It
                                                                                                                          makes us eager to study the laws of       the universe, that we
                                                                                                                          may live in accordance with them, and     diminish some of the
                                                                                                                          gross ignorance which   now prevails with all its attendant
                                                                                                                          evils ; while at the same time it leads even the most in
                                                                                                                          structed to feel how extremely limited our knowledge     is,
                                                                                                                                                                                  and
                                                                                                                                                like inexperienced children, dependent
                                                                                                                          that we are, after all,
                                                                                                                          upon the love and power of our Maker to bring us safely
                                                                                                                          out of darkness into light.
